Tom’s Toy Store sells Good B in a perfectly competitive market with a downward-sloping demand curve and an upward-sloping supply curve. The market price is <math alttext="$21" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>21</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> per unit, and the total fixed cost is <math alttext="$50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Identify the profit-maximizing quantity. Explain using marginal analysis.

(b) Calculate the economic profit at the profit-maximizing quantity you identified in part (a). Show your work.

(c) Calculate the average fixed cost of producing <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> units. Show your work.

(d) Based on your answer to part (b), will the number of firms in the industry increase, decrease, or stay the same in the long run? Explain.

(e) Based on your answer to part (b), will the market price increase, decrease, or stay the same in the long run? Explain.

(f) The income elasticity of demand for Good B is <math alttext="1.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the cross-price elasticity of demand for teddy bears with respect to the price of Good B is <math alttext="negative 0.2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on your answer to part (e), what will happen to the demand for teddy bears? Explain.

(g) Now assume that the market in which Tom’s Toy Store operates is in long-run equilibrium.(i) Suppose the market demand for Good B increases. Will the profit-maximizing quantity of Good B for Tom’s Toy Store increase, decrease, or stay the same in the short run? Explain.(ii) Suppose instead the wages that Tom’s Toy Store pays its workers decrease. Will the profit-maximizing quantity of Good B for Tom’s Toy Store increase, decrease, or stay the same in the short run? Explain.
